title-group.article-title: Anomalies in Stock Market Pricing: Problems in Return Measurements*

permissions.copyright-statement: © 2006 by The University of Chicago. All rights reserved.

abstract.p: We study four asset pricing anomalies: market size, contrarian, momentum, and book‐to‐market premia. We first control for two biases. We control for delisting effects, which create a survivorship bias. We then control for microstructure distortions from the bid‐ask spread bounce, which upwardly biases returns when the bid‐ask spreads are large. We find that these two biases account for a substantial portion of the market size, contrarian, and book‐to‐market anomalies. While these bias effects are substantial, they do not invalidate the anomalies. Controlling for bias, the momentum premium strengthens.

fn.p: We have appreciated comments from an anonymous referee, Jennifer Conrad, Steve Jordan, Sean Reid, Andrey Ukhov, seminars at the University of Connecticut, the University of Rhode Island, and the Financial Management Association doctoral seminar. All errors are, of course, our own. Contact the corresponding author, Wentworth Boynton, atcboynton@newhaven.edu.

sec.label: I.
sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: The asset pricing literature concentrates primarily on risk‐based explanations for pricing returns. The intuition is that the investor’s premium is priced on a set of multifactor covariates that describe economic fundamentals. However, even before addressing the very difficult problem of choosing the appropriate covariates, researchers face a number of difficult questions. One question includes the role of nonrisk‐based frictions that might distort returns. While the risk‐based literature is large, the literature on nonrisk‐based explanations is comparatively small. Our study is advantageous because we keep the monthly return and control for two nonrisk‐based measures: delisting effects and microstructure distortions from the bid‐ask spread bounce. To give a fuller picture of pricing, we also measure the difference between the arithmetic and geometric returns. Below, we summarize the past literature of the four anomalies, state our methods, and summarize our results.

sec.label: A.
sec.title: Market‐Size Premium
sec.p: The market‐size raw return premium is the excess return from being long in smallest market decile and short in largest market decile. Fama and French (1992) show that beta does not price the size premium, and they argue that market size and book‐to‐market are fundamental risk factors. However, past research is inconclusive on what market size represents.1In recent years, several researchers note the poorer performance of small capitalization stocks, and they suggest that the small‐firm premium in the past may only have been an abnormally high chance event.2

fn.p: Specific explanations include (1) incomplete information for smaller‐firm pricing (Barry and Brown1984); (2) poorer small‐firm economic fundamentals, higher levels of distress, and higher leverage (Chan and Chen1991); (3) individual firm outliers in the smallest market‐size decile (Knez and Ready1997); (4) an underlying January effect (Keim1983,1989; Blume and Stambaugh1983); (5) transaction cost frictions and higher bid‐ask spreads (Stoll and Whaley1983; Amihud and Mendelson1986); (6) credit market rationing and higher costs of borrowing (Stiglitz and Weiss1981); and (7) a conditional asset pricing framework (Jagannathan and Wang1996).

sec.label: B.
sec.title: Contrarian Premium
sec.p: The contrarian raw return premium is the excess return from being long in past losers and short in winners when winner and loser stocks are ranked over a 3‐ or 5‐year period. De Bondt and Thaler (1985) are the first to report that stocks ranked as past losers in 36‐month and 60‐month tests outperform past winners. Their results immediately spawned an active research area. The central hypothesis is that stock returns initially overreact to news and that pricing errors correct slowly. This result generates a simple trading rule: stocks that perform well (poorly) in the past will do poorly (well) in the future. Ball and Kothari (1989), Ball, Kothari, and Shanken (1995), and Fama and French (1996) suggest that the premium is priced from risk‐based covariances. De Bondt and Thaler (1987), Chopra, Lakonishok, and Ritter (1992), and Lakonishok, Shleifer, and Vishny (1994) argue that these risk‐based explanations are not convincing. They propose that investors misprice. Several papers develop a behavioral pricing theory based on market overreaction.3

fn.p: As examples, see Barberis, Shleifer, and Vishny (1998), Daniel, Hirshleifer, and Subrahmanyam (1998), and Hong, and Stein (1999).

sec.label: C.
sec.title: Momentum Premium
sec.p: The momentum raw return premium is the excess return from being long in past losers and short in winners when winner and loser stocks are ranked on 6‐month past performance. The momentum premium, first reported by Jegadeesh and Titman (1993), is also among the most actively studied premia in finance. Momentum trading is the strategy of buying immediate past winners and selling losers. Jegadeesh and Titman (1993,2001), Fama and French (1996), and Grundy and Martin (2001) show that the single factor or the Fama and French (1993) three‐factor models do not price momentum. Rouwenhorst (1998) and Griffin, Ji, and Martin (2003) show momentum premia in foreign markets. Chordia and Shivakumar (2002) suggest that lagged macroeconomic factors explain the momentum premium. However, Griffin et al. (2003) show that macroeconomic covariates do not price returns outside of the United States. Like the contrarian premium, several papers develop a behavioral pricing theory based on market underreaction.

sec.label: D.
sec.title: Book‐to‐Market Premium
sec.p: The book‐to‐market raw return premium is the excess return from being long in the largest book‐to‐market decile and short in the smallest book‐to‐market decile. Fama and French (1992,1993,1996) extensively study the book‐to‐market premium in the United States. Fama and French (1998) show that the book‐to‐market premium is worldwide. Lakonishok et al. (1994) and Daniel and Titman (1997) suggest that the book‐to‐market premium is a characteristic that is useful as a trading rule. But Lewellen (1999) provides empirical evidence of a risk‐based explanation. Liew and Vassalou (2000) suggest that book‐to‐market is tied to economic growth. We study three influences on raw returns.

sec.label: E.
sec.title: Delisting Effects
sec.p: The delisting bias is a survivorship effect. The Center for Research in Security Prices (CRSP) monthly files do not include the return for either the first or last month of trading unless the stock trades for the complete month. Shumway (1997) and Shumway and Warther (1999) show that if the firm fails, because the adverse delisting is typically not fully anticipated, the delisting price is often much lower than the last price on the CRSP monthly file. Small, low‐price firms are at a greater risk for an adverse delisting. Failing to include the delisting returns upwardly biases the investor’s earnings. To remedy this problem, we attach the delisting return to the monthly returns file. We find that delisting effects are material to the raw return results in certain periods but are substantially less influential than measurement errors from monthly rebalancing.

sec.label: F.
sec.title: Measurement Errors
sec.p:
Measurement errors from microstructure frictions are triggered by monthly rebalancing (Blume and Stambaugh1983; Roll1983) and upwardly bias stock returns. Conrad and Kaul (1993) show that the measurement error increases as the proportional bid‐ask spread (the spread divided by the fundamental stock price) increases. The bias is
wheresis the proportional spread andnis the number of stocks in the portfolio. The formula predicts that bias increases with the size of the proportional spread. These influences are well known for portfolios that rebalance daily. However, there are no studies that analyze the effects of measurement error over the full history of CRSP pricing. A major contribution of this article is to provide a method to control for this distortion. The measurement‐error‐free metric that we propose is a useful device that we hope will have wide use for asset pricing tests.

sec.label: G.
sec.title: Arithmetic versus Geometric Returns
sec.p: We often form a zero‐cost portfolio long in one ranked measure, such as small stocks, and short in another, such as large stocks. The arithmetic mean grows with increases in the variance, positive skewness, and kurtosis of the portfolio return, but the geometric return does not.4As Cochrane (2005) notes, the higher volatility of the arithmetic return implies a larger call option value for the security. We find substantial differences between arithmetic and geometric returns for the size and contrarian anomalies. These differences concentrate in the early years of the CRSP data set.

fn.p: Roll (1983, n. 5) shows that the arithmetic average return is a positive function of the geometric return, the variance, the positive skewness, and other higher moments. We also know that when the portfolio returns are normally distributed, the arithmetic return is the geometric return plus one‐half the variance of the time series returns. We use logs to capture the geometric return experience.

sec.label: H.
sec.title: Summary and Organization
sec.p: Our central contribution is straightforward. We find that delisting bias is small but that measurement‐error bias is influential. Controlling for both biases, the size premium falls from 1.36% to .73% per month, the contrarian premium falls from .78% to .60% per month, and the book‐to‐market premium falls from 1.32% to 1.01% per month. In contrast, the momentum premium increases from .42% to .71% per month.

We organize the remainder of the article as follows.Section IIdescribes the data sources.Section IIIdescribes the ranking methods for forming portfolios for the different anomaly tests.Section IVis an overview of the different returns that we use to measure investor experience.Section Vpresents the results.Section VIconcludes.

sec.label: II.
sec.title: Data
sec.p: We use the CRSP monthly closing prices, returns, and the number of shares outstanding. We include all firms except for those that are certificates, American Depository Receipts, units of beneficial interest, companies outside the United States, Americus Trust certificates, closed end funds, and real estate trusts.5For the book‐to‐market tests, we use COMPUSTAT item 60 plus deferred income taxes (COMPUSTAT item 74) less preferred stock (COMPUSTAT item 10). Consistent with many past papers, our market size and contrarian tests utilize New York Stock Exchange (NYSE) stocks, our momentum tests utilize NYSE and American Stock and Options Exchange (AMEX) stocks, and our book‐to‐market tests use NYSE, AMEX, and NASDAQ stocks.

The CRSP monthly files do not include either the first or last month of trading unless it is a complete month. To control for delisting bias, we append the delisting record onto the CRSP monthly returns.

fn.p: We select stocks that have the share code classification of 10 or 11 on the CRSP file.

sec.label: A.
sec.title: Market‐Size Portfolio Formation
sec.p: To determine rankings by size for the NYSE stocks, each year, we multiply the CRSP monthly price by the outstanding number of shares. We rank stocks by market capitalization on June 30 and form size deciles, similar to Fama and French (1992,1993). We call “S1” the smallest market size and “S10” the largest. Following Banz (1981), we test only NYSE stocks. This restriction to NYSE stocks allows the stock exchange variable to remain consistent across the 76‐year study period and allows comparison results to those of Banz (1981). After making tests on NYSE firms, we also made tests on NYSE/AMEX and NASDAQ firms and found similar results to those we report. We report results for the NYSE to save space.

sec.label: B.
sec.title: Contrarian Portfolio Formation
sec.p: De Bondt and Thaler (1985,1987) rank stocks using monthly returns from the previous 36 months. They rank stocks at calendar year‐ends. We also follow this approach.6We use a 36‐month past return ranking period and a 36‐month test period. We start the ranking period at January 1, 1927, and the first test period at January 1, 1930. De Bondt and Thaler (1985,1987) start their first 36‐month ranking period at January 1, 1930, and their first test period at January 1, 1933. Our approach gives one more 3‐year test period before the De Bondt and Thaler (1985) tests and adds seven 3‐year test periods through 2001. Similar to De Bondt and Thaler (1985,1987), we use NYSE stocks. We restrict stocks to those that have returns in the previous 36 months.

We form 20 portfolios ranked on past performance, denoting “C1” as the poorest and “C20” as the best past performing portfolio. Because there are approximately 600–1,200 common stocks on the NYSE that meet the requirement of having a return for the prior 36 months, our 20‐group ranking setup is similar to the 35–50 extreme winner and loser past performers setup adopted by De Bondt and Thaler (1985,1987).7

fn.p: Chopra et al. (1992) and Ball et al. (1995) use buy and hold rankings. Loughran and Ritter (1996) show that monthly average returns and buy and holds yield comparable test portfolio returns.
Chopra et al. (1992) and Ball et al. (1995) use 20 groups of stocks for contrarian tests.

sec.label: C.
sec.title: Momentum Portfolio Formation

sec.label: D.
sec.title: Book‐to‐Market Portfolio Formation
sec.p: To compute book value, we use COMPUSTAT data from the previous fiscal year and rank firms by book‐to‐market each June 30. We call “B1” the lowest book‐to‐market decile and “B10” the highest book‐to‐market decile. The approach is similar to that of Fama and French (1992,1993), except that we use an equally weighted measure while they use a value‐weighted one.

sec.label: IV.
sec.title: Return Measurement Influences
sec.p: We define below three types of monthly raw returns: (1) the rebalanced return, the standard metric in previous tests; (2) the corrected return, which controls for delisting and rebalancing effects; and the (3) log‐corrected return, which transforms the corrected portfolio return with natural logs and estimates the geometric return.

sec.label: A.
sec.title: Rebalanced Return
sec.p:
Denote the individual stockiand the ranking groupj. The rebalanced portfolio return is from averaging individual stock returns each month, which implies an equal weighting of the stock returns. The rebalanced return is
whererbdenotes “rebalanced,”nis the number of stocks that start in the test period, and \documentclass{aastex} \usepackage{amsbsy} \usepackage{amsfonts} \usepackage{amssymb} \usepackage{bm} \usepackage{mathrsfs} \usepackage{pifont} \usepackage{stmaryrd} \usepackage{textcomp} \usepackage{portland,xspace} \usepackage{amsmath,amsxtra} \usepackage[OT2,OT1]{fontenc} \newcommand\cyr{ \renewcommand\rmdefault{wncyr} \renewcommand\sfdefault{wncyss} \renewcommand\encodingdefault{OT2} \normalfont \selectfont} \DeclareTextFontCommand{\textcyr}{\cyr} \pagestyle{empty} \DeclareMathSizes{10}{9}{7}{6} \begin{document} \landscape $\delta _{t}( \delta _{t}\leq n) $ \end{document} is the number of stocks in the portfolio each month.

We can explain measurement errors with a simple example. Assume a portfolio of stocks, each of which has the same low fundamental value of $1 and a bid‐ask spread of 1/4. Assume that monthly prices randomly bounce back and forth between the bid and ask. At any given month‐end, half of the stocks have closing prices at 1 1/8, and half have closing prices at 7/8. Of the stocks at 7/8, half will move up and close at 1 1/8, and half will remain at 7/8. Of the stocks at 1 1/8, half will move down and close at 7/8, and half will remain at 1 1/8. When a stock bounces down from 1 1/8 to 7/8, the loss is 2/9. When a stock bounces up from 7/8 to 1/8, the gain is 2/7. Thus, gains from bounces up are greater than losses from bounces down, and this monthly cross‐sectional averaging induces a bias. In this example, the portfolio generates a bias of 1.59% per month, or 19% per year. Conrad and Kaul (1993) also provide a good description of how the rebalancing creates an upward bias.

sec.label: B.
sec.title: Corrected Return

sec.label: C.
sec.title: Log‐Corrected Returns

sec.label: D.
sec.title: Definitions
sec.p: We define “delisting bias” as the difference between the mean of the rebalanced CRSP monthly returns first without the delisting records and then with the delisting records. Based on Shumway's (1997) results, we hypothesize positive delisting bias for ranked portfolios dominated by small, low‐price stocks.

After controlling for delisting effects, we define “rebalancing bias” as the difference between the mean of the rebalanced returns and the mean of the corrected returns. As indicated by Blume and Stambaugh (1983), Roll (1983), and Conrad and Kaul (1993), if the individual stock returns are negatively correlated because of bid‐ask bounce, then the rebalancing bias is positive. We hypothesize a positive rebalancing bias for S1 (small market capitalization), C1 (past losers in 36‐month rankings), P1 (past losers in 6‐month rankings), and B10 (high book‐to‐market) stocks.

After controlling for delisting and rebalancing effects, we define the “arithmetic effect” as the difference between the arithmetic‐corrected and the log‐corrected returns. Since previous research shows that portfolios of small‐firm stocks have higher variances, we hypothesize a positive arithmetic effect. We have no prior knowledge on the signs of the other tests.

We find that the delisting bias does exist, but it is relatively small when compared with the monthly rebalancing bias. Shumway (1997) and Shumway and Warther (1999) also report on delisting problems, and our results are similar. To save space in the tables, we combine the delisting and rebalancing biases.

sec.label: V.
sec.title: Results
sec.p: We present results for the most extreme deciles (S1, S10, C1, C20, …) and the zero‐investment arbitrage portfolios (S1–S10, C1–C20, …).

sec.label: A.
sec.title: Market Size
sec.p:
Table 1shows the returns for the seven 10‐year and one 6‐year study periods and for the full 76‐year period. We report the returns for S1 (small stocks), S10 (large stocks), and S1–S10 (the size premium). From left to right, we report the arithmetic averages of the rebalanced returns (the standard monthly metric for most tests), the arithmetic averages of the returns corrected for rebalancing and delisting bias (our corrected returns), and then the log‐corrected returns (which give estimates of the geometric returns). We then use these monthly, portfolio wealth relatives as prices to generate the time series returns free of rebalancing bias. For decilejat montht, we define monthly, corrected return as \documentclass{aastex} \usepackage{amsbsy} \usepackage{amsfonts} \usepackage{amssymb} \usepackage{bm} \usepackage{mathrsfs} \usepackage{pifont} \usepackage{stmaryrd} \usepackage{textcomp} \usepackage{portland,xspace} \usepackage{amsmath,amsxtra} \usepackage[OT2,OT1]{fontenc} \newcommand\cyr{ \renewcommand\rmdefault{wncyr} \renewcommand\sfdefault{wncyss} \renewcommand\encodingdefault{OT2} \normalfont \selectfont} \DeclareTextFontCommand{\textcyr}{\cyr} \pagestyle{empty} \DeclareMathSizes{10}{9}{7}{6} \begin{document} \landscape $r^{c}_{j,t}=( WR_{j,t}) /( WR_{j,t-1}) -1$ \end{document} . Finally, we adjust the corrected returns with natural logs, \documentclass{aastex} \usepackage{amsbsy} \usepackage{amsfonts} \usepackage{amssymb} \usepackage{bm} \usepackage{mathrsfs} \usepackage{pifont} \usepackage{stmaryrd} \usepackage{textcomp} \usepackage{portland,xspace} \usepackage{amsmath,amsxtra} \usepackage[OT2,OT1]{fontenc} \newcommand\cyr{ \renewcommand\rmdefault{wncyr} \renewcommand\sfdefault{wncyss} \renewcommand\encodingdefault{OT2} \normalfont \selectfont} \DeclareTextFontCommand{\textcyr}{\cyr} \pagestyle{empty} \DeclareMathSizes{10}{9}{7}{6} \begin{document} \landscape $r^{\mathrm{ln}\,( c) }_{j,t}=\mathrm{ln}\,[ ( WR_{j,t}) /( WR_{j,t-1}) ] $ \end{document} to estimate the geometric return. The table shows the standard (monthly rebalanced), corrected, and log‐corrected raw returns. We test if the raw return market‐size premium (long in S1 and short in S10) is different than zero with Newey and Westt‐values, shown in brackets. Finally, to aid in the summary of the results, at the bottom of the table, we present the annualized returns from compounding the mean monthly returns.

The 76‐year rebalanced monthly mean S1 return is 2.30% (31.4% per year), and the S10 return is .93% (11.7% per year). The table reports strong small‐firm premia, especially in the July 1926–June 1936, July 1936–June 1946, and July 1976–June 1986 periods. For the corrected returns, the monthly S1 return is 1.66% (21.8% per year), and the S10 return is .93% (11.7% per year). The majority of the corrections occur during the July 1926–June 1936, July 1936–June 1946, and July 1986–June 1996 periods. The log‐corrected monthly S1 return is 1.11% (14.2% per year), and the S10 return is 0.78% (9.7% per year).

For S1–S10, the 76‐year rebalanced premium is 1.36% per month (t‐value: 4.09), and the corrected return is .73% per month (t‐value: 2.45). Measurement errors and delisting biases account for more than 40% of the premium. The log‐corrected premium is .33% per month (t‐value: 1.42).

sec.label: B.
sec.title: Contrarian
sec.p:
Table 2shows the returns for the eight 9‐year study periods and the full 72‐year period.Table 2reports the returns for C1 (past losers), C20 (past winners), and C1–C20 (the contrarian premium). As in the market‐size tests, in the table layout, from left to right, we report the arithmetic averages of the rebalanced returns, the arithmetic averages of the returns corrected for rebalancing and delisting bias (the corrected returns), and then the log‐corrected returns. Table 2
Contrarian Premia Tests: January 1, 1930–December 31, 2001
Period Rebalanced Corrected Log‐Corrected
C1 C20

C1 C20
\documentclass{aastex} \usepackage{amsbsy} \usepackage{amsfonts} \usepackage{amssymb} \usepackage{bm} \usepackage{mathrsfs} \usepackage{pifont} \usepackage{stmaryrd} \usepackage{textcomp} \usepackage{portland,xspace} \usepackage{amsmath,amsxtra} \usepackage[OT2,OT1]{fontenc} \newcommand\cyr{ \renewcommand\rmdefault{wncyr} \renewcommand\sfdefault{wncyss} \renewcommand\encodingdefault{OT2} \normalfont \selectfont} \DeclareTextFontCommand{\textcyr}{\cyr} \pagestyle{empty} \DeclareMathSizes{10}{9}{7}{6} \begin{document} \landscape $\mathrm{C}\,1-\mathrm{C}\,20$ \end{document}
January 1930–December 1938 3.61 1.56 2.05[2.25] 2.19 .48 1.71[1.98] .61 −.52 1.13[1.49]
January 1939–December 1947 3.28 1.36 1.92[2.53] 2.86 1.27 1.58[2.13] 2.12 .77 1.35[2.27]
January 1948–December 1956 1.79 1.19 .60[1.83] 1.73 1.23 .50[1.55] 1.60 1.08 .52[1.60]
January 1957–December 1965 1.63 1.15 .48[2.05] 1.76 1.24 .51[2.19] 1.60 1.11 .49[2.11]
January 1966–December 1974 .33 −.23 .55[2.32] .40 −.08 .48[1.79] .17 −.33 .50[1.84]
January 1975–December 1983 2.61 2.46 .15[.34] 2.54 2.55 −.01[−.03] 2.16 2.33 −.17[−.45]
January 1984–December 1992 1.22 .72 .50[1.69] .66 .77 −.10[−.20] .36 .59 −.23[−.44]
January 1993–December 2001 1.11 1.09 .02[.06] 1.28 1.16 .08[.16] 1.08 .91 .18[.36]
January 1930–December 2001 1.94 1.16 .78[3.79] 1.68 1.08 .60[3.11] 1.21 .74 .47[2.75]
Yearly returns 26.9 14.8 9.8 22.1 13.8 7.4 15.5 9.3 5.8
Note.—The returns are for New York Stock Exchange/American Stock and Options Exchange firms from the Center for Research in Security Prices. We rank stocks by past 36‐month cumulative return performance and form 20 past performance stock groups. We test performance for the 36 months after ranking. We call C1 the past losers and C20 as the past winners. We use nonoverlapping tests. The first ranking period period is January 1926–December 1929, and the first test period is January 1930–December 1932. We measure contrarian trading with three returns—rebalanced, corrected, and log‐corrected—as defined intable 1. We test the difference between the long (past loser) and short (past winner) positions. We test the contrarian premium with Newey and Westt‐values, shown in brackets. Finally, we present the annualized returns from compounding the monthly returns.

For the rebalanced return, C1 (past losers) earns 1.94% per month (26.9% per year), and C20 (past winners) earns 1.16% per month (14.8% per year). There are strong contrarian premia, especially during the January 1930–December 1947 and January 1984–December 1992 periods. For the corrected returns, the C1 monthly return falls to 1.68% (22.1% per year), and the C10 monthly return falls to 1.08% (13.8% per year). The majority of the corrections occur during the January 1930–December 1947 and January 1984–December 1992 periods. The log‐corrected C1 return is 1.21% (15.5% per year), and the C20 return is .74% (9.3% per year).

For C1–C20, the 72‐year rebalanced return is .78% per month (t‐value: 3.79), the corrected return is .60% per month (t‐value: 3.11), and the log‐corrected return is .47% per month (t‐value: 2.75). For the corrected and log‐corrected returns, the premium is earned in earlier portions of the sample. Contrarian strategies have neutral performance in more recent years.

Ourtable 2tests involve sorts at calendar year‐ends. One issue that may confound the contrarian anomaly is the January premium (Keim1983,1989). If security prices initially overreact to news and pricing errors slowly adjust, the contrarian premium, as suggested by the market overreaction hypothesis, should be independent of sorts made at year‐end. Further, Bhardwaj and Brooks (1992) show that forming portfolios at year‐end is more expensive than at other month‐ends. Ball et al. (1995) use both December 31 and June 30 year‐ends for their tests, and they show some differences in results for these two sort dates. We also sort stocks at June 30 by past performance and use nonoverlapping tests similar to ourtable 2tests. We report, but do not include the tables to save space, that the C1–C20 corrected (log‐corrected) returns fall to 4%–5% (3%–4%) per year and appear mostly in the early years of CRSP pricing.

sec.label: C.
sec.title: Momentum
sec.p: Recall that the market size and contrarian tests go long in stocks that have rebalancing and delisting biases and higher portfolio variances and short in stocks that are comparatively free of bias and have lower variances. In the case of momentum, it turns out that the reverse is true. Past losers (the short portfolio) have distortions and are overstated, and past winners (the long portfolio) are fairly specified.

Table 3presents the momentum test returns for the seven 10‐year and one 6‐year study periods and for the full 76‐year period. We report the returns for P1 (past losers), P10 (past winners), and \documentclass{aastex} \usepackage{amsbsy} \usepackage{amsfonts} \usepackage{amssymb} \usepackage{bm} \usepackage{mathrsfs} \usepackage{pifont} \usepackage{stmaryrd} \usepackage{textcomp} \usepackage{portland,xspace} \usepackage{amsmath,amsxtra} \usepackage[OT2,OT1]{fontenc} \newcommand\cyr{ \renewcommand\rmdefault{wncyr} \renewcommand\sfdefault{wncyss} \renewcommand\encodingdefault{OT2} \normalfont \selectfont} \DeclareTextFontCommand{\textcyr}{\cyr} \pagestyle{empty} \DeclareMathSizes{10}{9}{7}{6} \begin{document} \landscape $\mathrm{P}\,10-\mathrm{P}\,1$ \end{document} (the momentum premium). Table 3

July 1956–June 1966 .64 1.61 .97[4.61] .54 1.63 1.09[5.16] .40 1.50 1.10[5.46]
July 1966–June 1976 .84 1.06 .22[.40] .49 1.02 .53[1.02] .01 .76 .74[1.59]
July 1976–June 1986 1.27 2.29 1.02[3.54] 1.08 2.36 1.28[4.42] .90 2.12 1.22[4.13]

Yearly returns 15.4 21.3 5.2 10.0 19.7 8.9 4.3 15.4 10.7
Note.—The returns are for New York Stock Exchange/American Stock and Options Exchange firms from the Center for Research in Security Prices. We rank stocks by past 6‐month cumulative return performance and form past performance stock deciles. We test performance for the 6 months after ranking. We define P1 as the past loser portfolio, P10 as the past winner portfolio, and \documentclass{aastex} \usepackage{amsbsy} \usepackage{amsfonts} \usepackage{amssymb} \usepackage{bm} \usepackage{mathrsfs} \usepackage{pifont} \usepackage{stmaryrd} \usepackage{textcomp} \usepackage{portland,xspace} \usepackage{amsmath,amsxtra} \usepackage[OT2,OT1]{fontenc} \newcommand\cyr{ \renewcommand\rmdefault{wncyr} \renewcommand\sfdefault{wncyss} \renewcommand\encodingdefault{OT2} \normalfont \selectfont} \DeclareTextFontCommand{\textcyr}{\cyr} \pagestyle{empty} \DeclareMathSizes{10}{9}{7}{6} \begin{document} \landscape $\mathrm{P}\,10-\mathrm{P}\,1$ \end{document} as the momentum premium. As is standard, we use overlapping test designs. The first ranking period period is January 1926–June 1926, and the first test month is July 1926. We measure momentum with three returns—rebalanced, corrected, and log‐corrected—which are described intable 1. In the momentum strategy, each month, the investor holds six portfolios of winner stocks and six portfolios of loser stocks. Long and short portfolios were formed 1 month ago, 2 months ago, etc. Each month, the portfolio from 6 months earlier is sold, and a new portfolio is formed based on the trading rule. We test the raw return momentum premium ( \documentclass{aastex} \usepackage{amsbsy} \usepackage{amsfonts} \usepackage{amssymb} \usepackage{bm} \usepackage{mathrsfs} \usepackage{pifont} \usepackage{stmaryrd} \usepackage{textcomp} \usepackage{portland,xspace} \usepackage{amsmath,amsxtra} \usepackage[OT2,OT1]{fontenc} \newcommand\cyr{ \renewcommand\rmdefault{wncyr} \renewcommand\sfdefault{wncyss} \renewcommand\encodingdefault{OT2} \normalfont \selectfont} \DeclareTextFontCommand{\textcyr}{\cyr} \pagestyle{empty} \DeclareMathSizes{10}{9}{7}{6} \begin{document} \landscape $\mathrm{P}\,10-\mathrm{P}\,1$ \end{document} ) with Newey and Westt‐values, which we report in brackets. Finally, we present the annualized returns from compounding the monthly returns.

The 76‐year P10 rebalanced monthly return is 1.62% (21.3% per year); the P1 monthly return is 1.20% (15.4% per year). The rebalanced returns reported here are similar to the results in the literature. Jegadeesh and Titman (1993) note that the momentum strategy earns negative returns in the early history of CRSP pricing. Thetable 3rebalanced return results are similar. For the corrected returns, the P10 monthly return is 1.51% (19.7% per year), and the P1 monthly return is .80% (10.0% per year). With these corrections, the premium becomes stronger across all the past performance test periods, suggesting that momentum is more pronounced than past papers suggest. The log‐corrected monthly P10 return is 1.20% (15.4% per year), and the P1 return is .35% (4.3% per year).

sec.label: D.
sec.title: Book‐to‐Market
sec.p:
Table 4shows the returns for the three 10‐year study periods, one 6‐year period, and for the full 36‐year period, July 1966–June 2002. We report the returns for B10 (high book‐to‐market), B1 (low book‐to‐market), and \documentclass{aastex} \usepackage{amsbsy} \usepackage{amsfonts} \usepackage{amssymb} \usepackage{bm} \usepackage{mathrsfs} \usepackage{pifont} \usepackage{stmaryrd} \usepackage{textcomp} \usepackage{portland,xspace} \usepackage{amsmath,amsxtra} \usepackage[OT2,OT1]{fontenc} \newcommand\cyr{ \renewcommand\rmdefault{wncyr} \renewcommand\sfdefault{wncyss} \renewcommand\encodingdefault{OT2} \normalfont \selectfont} \DeclareTextFontCommand{\textcyr}{\cyr} \pagestyle{empty} \DeclareMathSizes{10}{9}{7}{6} \begin{document} \landscape $\mathrm{B}\,10-\mathrm{B}\,1$ \end{document} (the book‐to‐market premium). July 1966–June 1976 .53 1.54 1.01[2.59] .59 1.29 .70[1.84] .34 .99 .65[1.77]
July 1976–June 1986 1.27 2.32 1.05[2.11] 1.23 2.22 .99[1.93] .95 2.08 1.13[2.24]
July 1986–June 1996 .32 1.93 1.61[3.93] .26 1.43 1.17[2.16] .06 1.28 1.22[2.84]

Yearly returns 7.4 25.6 17.0 7.1 20.7 12.8 3.3 17.9 14.2
Note.—The returns are for New York Stock Exchange, American Stock and Options Exchange, and NASDAQ firms from the Center for Research in Security Prices. For the book‐to‐market tests, we use COMPUSTAT item 60 plus deferred income taxes (COMPUSTAT item 74) less preferred stock (COMPUSTAT item 10). We make sorts on the book‐to‐market ratio on June 30 every year from 1966 to 2001 and form book‐to‐market deciles. We define B1 as the lowest and B10 as the largest book‐to‐market deciles. The table shows returns for three 10‐year and one 6‐year trials and for the 36‐year period from July 1966 to June 2002. We compute three types of portfolio returns—rebalanced, corrected, and log‐corrected—as outlined intable 1. We test the book‐to‐market premium ( \documentclass{aastex} \usepackage{amsbsy} \usepackage{amsfonts} \usepackage{amssymb} \usepackage{bm} \usepackage{mathrsfs} \usepackage{pifont} \usepackage{stmaryrd} \usepackage{textcomp} \usepackage{portland,xspace} \usepackage{amsmath,amsxtra} \usepackage[OT2,OT1]{fontenc} \newcommand\cyr{ \renewcommand\rmdefault{wncyr} \renewcommand\sfdefault{wncyss} \renewcommand\encodingdefault{OT2} \normalfont \selectfont} \DeclareTextFontCommand{\textcyr}{\cyr} \pagestyle{empty} \DeclareMathSizes{10}{9}{7}{6} \begin{document} \landscape $\mathrm{B}\,10-\mathrm{B}\,1$ \end{document} ) with Newey and Westt‐values, shown in brackets. Finally, we present the annualized returns from compounding the monthly returns.

The 36‐year monthly B1 return is .60% (7.4% per year), and the B10 monthly return is 1.92% (25.6% per year). The corrected monthly B1 return is .57% (7.1% per year), while the corrected B10 monthly return is 1.58% (20.7% per year). The log‐corrected B1 monthly return is 0.27% (3.3% per year), and the log‐corrected B10 monthly return is 1.38% (17.9% per year).
The book‐to‐market premium with rebalanced returns is 1.32% (t‐value: 5.01). The premium with corrected returns is 1.01% (t‐value: 3.73). The log‐corrected premium is 1.11% (t‐value: 4.11).

sec.label: VI.
sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: We test three influences for the market size, contrarian, momentum, and book‐to‐market pricing anomalies. Corrections for bias cause declines in the premia for market size, contrarian, and book‐to‐market strategies and increase the premium in the momentum strategy. In all four tests, we use equally weighted portfolio returns. We also make tests with value‐weighted designs. We find that value weighting reduces, but does not eliminate, bias effects.
